# 270\n
{London, British Library, Royal 12 E i, fol. 194v, hand B: versions of My Leman on the Rood, and Thenk man}\n
C13b2-C14a1\n
562 321 E\n
{=NW Norfolk=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{~f194v~}\n

{=Enlarged coloured initial *Q=}\n
$/P11N_HIC\n

\'_IHesU\n
$/P11GOd+C_MI\n

# 260\n
{London, British Library, Royal 17 A xxvii, fols. 1r-8v, 11r-45v, hand A: Sawles Warde (part), St Katherine, St Margaret (part)}\n
C13a1\n
367 276 N\n
{=SE Salop=}\n
{=Sample tagged: fols. 1r-8v; 11r-37r (i.e. St Margaret not tagged)=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Gaps between words are very small. Sometimes it is difficult to know\n
whether to record two words as joined or not, but I have made\n
judgements according to the spacing of immediately surrounding text I\n
have realised the yogh letter as z although it does often have the\n
general shape of insular g. But it seems to me to be formed in much\n
the same way as the scribe of Bodley 34 forms his and these can hardly\n
still be said to be insular g=}\n
{~f1r~}\n
{(*SI SCIRET PATERFAMILIAS QUA ORA FUR UENTURUS \\ ESSET .\' UIGILARET\n
UTIQue & NON SINERET PerFODI \\ DOMUM SUAM .(}\n
{=Three-line decorated coloured initial *S on *SI with decorative\n
elements reaching into the top margin and five further lines down in the\n
left hand margin.  In the Latin following MS has NONSI NERET with\n
an erasure between SI and NERET and separation lines between NON and SI\n
indicating the originally mistaken word division=}\n
$/P21G_*VRE\n
{=Somewhat enlarged coloured and decorated initial *V=}\n

$to/im+C_TO\n
$e:acan/vi-m_ECH+EN $/vi-m_+EN\n
{.\'}\n
{=Wilson 1938 realises this as a punctus elevatus, but it is not the\n
usual kind. It looks more as if at the end of the line the scribe\n
erroneously began a third minim to make M instead of required N, then\n
realised his mistake and turned the half minim into the top oblique\n
stroke of a punctus elevatus and supplied the dot below it to cover his\n
error. None of the other versions have any punctuation at this point and\n
arguably it is not appropriate here=}\n
{\\}\n
$/P23G_HARE\n
$pi:ne/nplOd_PIN+EN $/plnOd_+EN\n
{.}\n
$/TplN_yE\n
$loth/ajpl_LAd+E $/plaj_+E\n

$toad/npl_TADD+EN $/pln_+EN\n
$&/cj_&\n
$frog/npl_FR>O>GG+EN $/pln_+EN\n
{=O interlined above. I have realised this as if it is a missing O\n
subsequently supplied rather than superscript O that normally implies also\n
a preceding <r>, because the fully written R is already there=}\n
{.}\n
$/RTApl_y~\n
$fretan/vps23_FREO\\T+Ed $/vps23_+Ed\n
$/P23Oi_HAM\n

$/TplOd-ad_TE\n
$eye/nplOd_EHNEN\n

$ruen/vps13_RUU+Ed $/vps13[N]_+Ed\n
{=Or read RUNEd "runs" Wilson (1938) reads RUUEd here but RUNEd in \n
Titus. He says (probably rightly) that RUNEd cannot be the correct\n
reading for semantic reasons and accepts Hall\'s (1928) suggestion that\n
RUUEd is from an otherwise unattested verb *ruuen related to "ruffle"\n
meaning "to stand on end". In fact the verb "ruff" is attested, albeit\n
only from C16, in the context of a hawk raising its feathers to a more\n
erect position. Here I follow MED\'s headword (from Bodley\'s RUEd) but\n
acknowledging that ruuen, rouen with intervocalic [v] is also possible=}\n
$up/av_UP\n
{.\'}\n

$have/vps13_HAU+Ed $/vps13_+Ed\n
$lae:nan/vpp_I+LEAN+ET $ge-/xp-vpp_I+ $/vpp[N]_+ET\n
{=Wilson says MS GILEANET with G corrected from g. This is not right. The\n
first letter is not a G at all and is not corrected from anything. It was a\n
perfectly ordinary H missing the final bar at the top of the ascender - presumably\n
the scribe realised his mistake before finishing the letter - and it is subpuncted\n
for removal. Read therefore ILEANET=}\n
$/P13OiM_HIM\n

$/P12N_yU\n
$/P13OdI_HIT\n
$gieldan/vSpt12_zULDE\n
{*sj context*}\n
{=d\'Ardenne & Dobson (1981) say that the yoghs on zEF and zULDE are\n
abnormal and \'a mixed letter\' between yogh and G.  The shape is nothing\n
like this scribe\'s normal Anglian two-compartment G which is made with\n
two bold bows in opposite directions and both closed, with the second\n
going well below the line and closed with a diagonal hairline, and with\n
a clear off-stroke on the right hand side of the first bow. THe yogh is\n
formed like a small Textura S at minim height and never goes below the\n
line. It has a decoratively waving top stroke in the shape of a modern\n
tilde. Occasionally this stroke is angled somewhat downwards from left\n
to right which is what has happened here. It is not especially abnormal\n
for this scribe=} \n
$&/cj_&\n
$give/vSpt12_zEUE\n
{*sj context*}\n
$to/pr+H_TO\n

{=So says MED. Or might be from agaelwan? See note in d\'Ardenne & Dobson\n
(1981). It requires to alliterate on [g] not [j] so if from a3en "awe"\n
it must be a Scandinavian influenced spelling. Agaelwan seems too distant\n
in spelling to be plausible. I\'m not wholly convinced by either of these\n
readings. There could perhaps be a connection with Anglo-Norman\n
aguait(er) "trap, snare, ambush" but this too seems doubtful and would\n
fit less well with Titus AGIDE=}\n

$nowhere/av-k_NOw+HwER $where/av-k_+HwER\n
{=NB this is a common form in the Titus texts. Titus has this apparently\n
diphthongal first element also at the same place in the running text\n
of St Katherine, and once later where Royal does not have it. But the\n
spelling also appears in Royal once in the Life of St Margaret. The\n
same kind of spellings happen also in the words "o:where", "o:whither"\n
and "nowhither" and they look to be forms common to whatever lies\n
behind T and R or, since it appears in all but one of T\'s texts, maybe\n
it\'s a NW Midland spelling and R has got it via the NW Midland version\n
behind T. Compare however Orm\'s OwwHAR and NAU+ spellings in Trinity\n
Homilies and Vices and Virtues in the East Midlands, and NOU+ spellings\n
in Laud Misc 108 hand A and the Nero version of Ancrene Riwle in the SW\n
Midlands=}\n

\n
# 261\n
{London, British Library, Royal 17 A xxvii, fols. 9r-10v, 58v-70v, hand B: ends of Sawles Warde and of St Juliana, the Oreisun of Seinte Marie}\n
C13a1\n
367 276 E\n
{=SE Salop=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation NOT yet done; tagging notes and\n
textual notes NOT up to date=}\n
{~f9r~}\n
{=Hand B takes over from Hand A to finish Sawles Warde. I have realised\n
yogh as z although it has somewhat the look of insular g. But it is\n
most like the form which the Bodley 34 scribe uses, which is made in\n
three strokes but is very stylised and can hardly any longer be called\n
insular g=}\n
$soft/aj_SOFTE\n
$or/cj_OdE*R\n
$sweet/aj_SwETE\n
$&/cj_&\n
$/P23G_HA*RE\n
$life/n_LIF\n
$be/vps13_IS\n
$in{m}/pr_IN\n
$god/nG_GOD+ES $/Gn_+ES\n
$sight/n<pr_SIH+dE $-th/xs-n<pr_+dE\n
$&/cj_&\n
$god/nG_GOD+ES $/Gn_+ES\n
$acknowledge/vn<pr_CNAw+LECH+UNGE $-lae:can/xs-vn<pr_+LECH+UNGE $/vn<pr_+UNGE\n
{\\}\n
$as/av_AS\n
$/P21G_U*RE\n
$lord/n_LAUerD\n
$say/vpt13_SEI+DE $/vpt13[V]_+DE\n
$/Datpn_y~\n
$be/vps13_IS\n

{=Usual \'Worcester\' form for this i.e. thorn with a stroke through the descender.\n
Cf. the other 2 hands of Royal, Nero AR and WG, Worcester TH, and a slightly\n
different variant in Cotton Aix lang 2 which has the line through the descender\n
plus the usual abbreviation for "there" sometimes also used for "that" i.e. y\n
with a hook to the ascender=}\n

$blood/n<pr_+BLOTE\n
{=d\'Ardenne (1961) reads BLODE. Some of the scribe\'s Ds are indeed very\n
T-like with very flat ascender and following E often joined to the\n
back of D (e.g. second D of DUDEN in following line). But here the\n
letter looks to be made with 2 separate strokes and the cross-bar\n
slightly below the stem of the letter as if it were formed as a T=}\n

{=Usual \'Worcester\' form for "through" i.e. thorn with a stroke through\n
the descender. Cf. the other 2 hands of Royal, Nero AR and WG, Worcester\n

has the line through the descender plus the usual abbreviation for\n
"there"  sometimes also used for "that" i.e. thorn with a hook to the ascender=}\n

$burst/vSpt13_BARST\n
$on/av_ON\n
$to/im+C_TO\n
$blain/vi-m_BLEIN+EN $/vi-m_+EN\n
{=OE ble:gen is a blister. The verb *ble:gnan is not recorded as such in\n
OE, but cf. from the A-S Leechdom \'wIy gEBLEgNADRE TUNgEN\' and a ME verb\n
is implied in the ME forms bleined and bleininge. Mack (1934) takes\n
the phrase to mean "burst into blisters". But ON-TO meaning "into" is\n
implausible for this date (though cf. MED s.v. bresten v. 2. (f)). But\n
"burst" + av + "to" + verb seems more comfortable to me in eME and is\n
perfectly OK in late ME. See MED s.v. bresten v. 3 (c) esp. Cuckoo and\n
Nightingale barst on for to wepe. This also makes sense of the past sg\n
in ARAS. The skin is the subject throughout=}\n
$that/cj_y~\n

$pi:nian/vps13K2_PIN+et $/vps13[N]K2_+et\n
{=This is not PIN[Ed] - miscited as yIN[Ed] - in Mack (1934) but PIN. It is\n
correctly cited in the footnote. And it is not followed by \'the stroke of\n
another letter\' but a small version of the Latin abbreviation for \'-et\'.\n
It is not the same as this scribe\'s letter yogh or quite identical to\n
his letter Z, although it is similar, so I have realised it separately\n
as \'et\' the lower case as usual indicating an abbreviation. At first\n
sight the word looks a bit like PU*R with majuscule shaped *R as in\n
OdE*R above, but this shape seems only to be used after E and "pure"\n
makes no sense in context anyway. The sense required is "suffers". Also,\n
there is a light stroke visible above the first minim indicating I=}\n
$of/pr_O+\n

{\\}\n
{~f55r~}\n
$main/n<pr_MAGIN\n
{=Mack (1934) thinks this should read GODD-I MAGIN "god imagine", "divine\n
image". Note that Bodley has GODD UN AGIN which Mack reads as IM AGIN\n
but the scribe usually gives a stroke to the I when it is ambiguous and\n
this has none. It appears again in line 4 of Juliana (though R leaves it\n
out unfortunately). It seems to be UNAGIN which d\'Ardenne (1961) takes to mean\n
without beginning, probably rightly. Here the R scribe must be reading\n
the four minims of IM UN as "in m-" and presumably thinks it is for\n
"in main" cf. "almighty". This is how I take it anyway=}\n
$worship/n_wURd+SCHIPE $-ship/xs-n_+SCHIPE\n

{=End of hand C\'s text. Hand B takes over at top of fol. 58v and\n

\n
# 64\n
{London, British Library, Stowe 34, hand A, pp. 1-74 line 17; 74 line 22 -75 line 3: Vices and Virtues}\n
C13a1\n
547 207 E\n
{=SW Essex=}\n
{=Sample represents all the English in this hand. The beginning of the MS is lost=}\n
{=Script - early C13 proto-Gothic informal script most strongly influenced\n
by contemporary documentary hand=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{~p1~}\n
{=Begins imperfectly. The Latin quotations within the text are\n
underlined in the manuscript. Contemporary titles are in red and\n
appear to have been added after the main text was written, because\n
there is not always room for them and they usually spill into the\n
right margin. They are in a different hand from either of the two\n
main hands contributing to the manuscript and have here been\n
bracketed out accordingly. They are tagged separately as text 302\n
(vvtit.tag). There appears also to be several other contemporary\n
correcting hands, apart from Scribes A and B themselves who make running\n
corrections to their own work. The main correcting scribe provides a number\n
of additions to the main text. His work is bracketed out here in the usual\n
way but labelled as being by the main correcting scribe where the attribution\n
is clear. His contributions are tagged separately as text 303 (vvcorrt.tag).\n
Insertions apparently made by Scribe A himself are noted and included\n
in the tagged text in the usual way. Any corrections that are\n
apparently not by Scribe A or by the main correcting hand are\n
bracketed out and labelled as being by a different hand but are\n
otherwise left unattributed and have not been tagged. Some initial\n
letters within sections have been touched with colour to indicate\n
that they are litterae notabiliores, whether or not they are\n
capitalised. It is not always possible on the black and white\n
microfilm to identify these letters. I have preceded such letters\n
with * where I am reasonably sure they have been so coloured. I have\n
not attempted to differentiate Tironian "and" signs that are coloured in\n
this way. The text block also has a separate column on the left hand\n
side that is sometimes used for initial capitals within sections.\n
Letters placed in this left hand column are also here given\n
preceding *. Holthausen\'s (1888) edition repunctuates and\n
recapitalises so cannot be used as a guide to manuscript\n
capitalisation. Note that Holthausen prints yogh where I print\n
insular g (realised here in the usual way as lower case g). Where\n
I refer to Holthausen\'s readings in notes I realise his yogh as\n
lower case z. Note that Holthausen translates all personified vices,\n
virtues and the soul as "it". The feminine pronoun forms are\n
consistently used for them, and although some grammatical gender\n
undoubtedly survives in this text in places where there is no sense that\n
the referent is an animate human, it seems to me that in many cases\n
in the text there is true personification. In these cases I treat the\n
pronoun as being fully gendered (with F in the grammel) rather than as\n
survivals of grammatical gender (with I in the grammel). However, the\n
personification is somewhat episodic, the virtues etc. seeming sometimes\n
to be mere abstractions and sometimes truly personified. Decisions are\n
made the more difficult because of the survival of grammatical gender\n
in this text language. Individual decisions are therefore open to\n
argument and possible reanalysis=}\n

{.}\n
{)*NU ANDSwEREd RATIO & SPEd TO yARE SAULE .)}\n
{=Written by the title scribe. Holthausen (1888) prints *HU, but\n
the first letter of the title is a standard H-shaped capital N.\n
He also prints SYEd, but this is not plausible as a spelling of\n
"says", and the second letter is clearly shaped like this\n
scribe\'s P - cf. BAFTEN^SPACHE above. I assume therefore that\n
it is for "speaks", perhaps in error for SPECd=}\n

$/Dis<pr_dESEN\n
{=It looks as if the N may have been added afterwards, yet the spacing\n
does not look narrower than usual even with the N=}\n
$e:adig/aj<pr_EAD+IgE $-ig/xs-aj<pr_+IgE\n
{=Holthausen prints EADIzEN, believing final N to be part of the scribal\n
correction, but I do not believe that final N is here intended - see below=}\n
$light/n<pr_LIHTE\n
{=The scribe first wrote dESE/dESEN EADIgE MIHTE. An N appears to have\n
been added to original dESE (see above). M has been corrected to L by\n
extending the third minim. The other two minims are left uncancelled,\n
and Holthausen has take this to imply they should be added to the end of\n
EADIgE as final N. There is no attempt to link the two minims to the end\n
of the previous word in any way, moreover N is very much a minority form\n
in this hand for the ending of adjectives, whether singular or plural. I\n
think the overwriting of part of the M could equally be taken to imply\n
its cancellation=}\n
$say/vpt13_SA+DE $/vpt13[V]_+DE\n

$give/vps12_[g]IF+ST $/vps12[F]_+ST\n
{=The scribe first wrote *G and then added an oblique hairline and a\n
stronger hook - below the main body of the letter to the left, to alter\n
it perhaps to a very rough approximation of his usual insular g. It is\n
possible that the intention was merely to change the capital *G to a\n
minuscule G. As there has been no attempt at erasure of the shape of\n
the original capital it is impossible to be sure of the scribe\'s intentions=}\n

{=After HI there has been an erasure of several letters. The M of HIM is\n
formed in a widely spaced manner (perhaps by a different hand), to fill\n
some of the additional space between whatver was originally written and\n

{<HERE<}\n
{=del, by underlining=}\n
{>}\n
{=ins, interlined above deletion by Scribe A himself. The first two Es\n
have subsequently been subpuncted to make gURE, whether by Scribe A or\n
a different correcting scribe is uncertain. Scribe A has a number of\n
different spellings for this pronoun including gEURE, gEUER, gEUERE and gURE=}\n

{=Holthausen (1888) comments that the second insular g is corrected from\n

$underfo:n/vps13_UNDER+FEN+d $under-/xp-v_UNDER+ $/vps13[K]_+d\n
{=MS UNDERFENGd with final G and edh amalgamated into a single shape\n
with the body of G doubling as the body of edh. Present tense not\n
past tense is needed, and given Scribe A\'s tendency often to correct\n
by overwriting without erasing the unwanted parts of the overwritten\n
letter, I take it that he intended edh to be read and not G, especially\n
as there is plenty of room at the end of the folio for him to have added\n
a final edh if he wanted. Holthausen (1888) reads UNDERFENGd with a\n
note to say that G and edh are "connected" which understates the case=}\n
{.}\n

$Yolian/vps12K2_yOL+EST $/vps12[L]K2_+EST\n
{.}\n
{)\'*OF FOR+[SCEAw]\\+NESS[E]\')}\n
{=Written by the title scribe. The title runs into the right margin.\n
The bracketed letters are not visible on the microfilm because of the\n
tightness of the binding. They are supplied from Holthausen (1888),\n
where the wynn is itself bracketed (as W) as being conjectured.\n
Holthausen adds that zAP has been written by another hand above SCEA.\n
Only the initial insular g is visible on the microfilm=}\n
{\\}\n
{>)\'*OF *PRUDENCE\')>}\n
{=ins, in left margin by a modern hand=}\n
{(*P*ROUIDEnTIA(}\n
{=Two-line coloured decorated initial *P with the descender extending\n
three further lines down in the left margin. Guide letter P in the left margin=}\n
$/Datpn_y~\n
$be/vps13_IS\n
$foreshowness/n_FOR+SCEAw+NESSE $fore-/xp-n_FOR+ $-ness/xs-n_+NESSE\n
{=First S and E subpuncted, presumably meant to include the intervening\n
C, and insular g added above by another hand, not the main correcting\n
hand. If the intended correction was again to FORgAPNESSE, the wynn must\n
have been intended to serve as P as it is left unaltered=}\n
$be/vps13_IS\n

$weila:/int_VVaeLLE\n
{=Holthausen (1888) reads *V*VELLE and says that the first E is\n
corrected from L. There is perhaps a crease in the parchment here. An\n
oblique line appears in the microfilm, running through the first letter\n
of the word which on the film looks more like a single V. But a slight\n
crease would easily cause this appearance and I take Holthausen\'s\n
reading from the original manuscript to be correct. The second\n
letter looks like Scribe A\'s usual form for aesc rather than a\n
correction from L to E, and that is how I read it here. Holthausen\n
translates the word "well", but I believe it is more likely to be the\n
interjection=}\n
$/P12-voc_dU\n

$if/cj_*G>J>IF\n
{=Scribe B very frequently inserts J between initial *G and I. It is not\n
at all clear what he means by this. The insertion is too frequent for it\n
to be likely that he really intended to write insular g or yogh. He uses\n
J occasionally elsewhere as a simple I-longa, so it presumably does not\n
imply a fricative, but serves perhaps as reinforcement of the palatal\n
pronunciation of the word in a script which elsewhere only once uses\n
an enlarged coloured insular g-shape as a capital (p. 76), and otherwise\n
only uses *G for the capital, whatever the likely phonetic context=}  \n
$/P12N_yU\n

$to/im+C_TO+\n
$gerian{*}/viK2-m_+>g>EAR+EN $/viK2-m_+EN\n
{=Originally TO EAREN. An infinitive was required, however. It looks as if\n
Scribe B himself added insular G between TO and EAREN to make TOgEAREN,\n
which I take to be a form from conjectured OE gerian "request, desire".\n
See MED s.v. ye:ren v. (1).  A later corrector then adds HE above in red to\n
make TOgEHEAREN, presumably "to hear" but this is not this text language\'s usual\n
spelling for "hear" and a word meaning "desire" makes stronger sense here=}\n
$/TOd_yE\n
$tongue/nOd_TUNGE\n
